column4: it didn't work. it says "Starting Up". and then there's a message in gibberish...
this time it didn't go back to the grub menu?
do you have an option in your BIOS to select the boot priority separately for your two hard disk drives?
try both. If grub fails to come up on one, it may be worth trying to leave it at that setting and reinstalling grub using the RecoveringUbuntu... procedure in the factoid:
can i access files on the windows's partition from the ubuntu?
i'm trying to mount that windows partition. http://paste.ubuntu.com/10915/
could be. This sounds like bad news, to be honest
just leave it as it is, in case you go back to a standard DOS MBR at some point
on the assumption that tovare is right, you could revert to a DOS MBR (just use any DOS-based rescue CD) and see if that lets Windows boot
do you know how to search it? There is a great service called "Google" :)
I don't have much experience, but I would start with FreeDOS. There is also something called UBD that I've used years ago (universal boot disk, I think)
once you have a DOS system running, it's a matter of running 'fdisk /fixmbr'. Perhaps you want to disconnect one of your disks, so you know for sure which one you are operating on
I think that's part of the problem. Your BIOS and Ubuntu disagree about which one is the first disk in your system.
logical vs. primary partitions never causes problems like yours
